titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Charles Templeman Loram Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Joan Williamson and Francis Radvonovsky

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 08:04

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, articles, reports, notes, lectures, memorabilia, and other papers of Charles Templeman Loram, educator and professor of education in South Africa and at Yale. Included are papers both from his work at Yale and his earlier work as an educational administrator in South Africa. There is also one box of records from the South Africa Native Affairs Commission.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Mrs. Charles T. Loram, 1940-1952; and Ian C. Loram, 1995.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Charles Templeman Loram Papers (MS 10). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in six series and one addition: I. Correspondence. II. Writings. III. Government Records. IV. Miscellaneous. V. Maps. VI. Pictures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Charles Templeman Loram (1879-1940) Papers document the life work of an internationally famous educator and professor of education in South Africa and at Yale. Most of the seventeen box collection consists of the writings of Professor Loram, his students and his colleagues on a wide variety of topics within the general fields of education, anthropology, religion, and race relations. Over three boxes in the papers consist of notebooks and notes compiled at the University of Cambridge.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Born in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, Loram was educated at the University of the Cape of Good Hope (B.A. 1900), and the University of Cambridge (B.A. and LL.B. 1905, M.A. 1908), and Columbia University (Ph.D. 1917). In Africa, Loram held a number of government positions in education. Beginning as a teacher at Pietermaritzburg College, he was inspector of schools in Natal (1906-1917), Chief Inspector of Native Education (1917-1920), a member of the Union of South Africa Native Affairs Commission (1920-1929), Chief Inspector of Education, Natal (1929-1930), and Superintendent of Education (1930-1931).

In 1931, Charles Loram was appointed Sterling Professor of Education at Yale University, holding the position until his death in 1940. He also served as chairman and director of studies in the department of culture contacts and race relations in the Yale Graduate School from 1933. Other positions and honors held by Loram include: member of the Phelps-Stokes commission to Africa, 1922, to East Africa, 1925; trustee of Yale-in-China, recipient of honorary M.A. Yale University, 1931, recipient of honorary ED.D. University of Colorado, 1937; and participant in many seminars and conferences on the American Indian, Negroes, Africans, and Pacific Islanders. He was the author of The Education of the South African Native , 1919.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence includes letters, minutes, reports, and lists of publications. Folders are arranged alphabetically by name of individuals or institutions. Within each folder the material is then arranged chronologically. The correspondence is primarily with religious organizations, including Berkeley Divinity School, Hartford Seminary Foundation, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, the World Sunday School Association, and several groups in China and the Pacific. Also included is information on the Phelps-Stokes Fund.

did.unittitle: Bernice P. Bishop Museum, Honolulu, Hawaii with minutes of meetings and list of publications
Phelps-Stokes Fund, with budget, estimated income, and proposed expenditure
Yale-in-China, with minutes of meetings, reports, and notes on missions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings include articles, reports, memoranda, book reviews, addresses, speeches, lectures, course and seminar outlines, college notebooks and notes, material from Boulder Seminar (1937), other people's writings, and theses written under Loram's supervision. Loram's articles, reports, speeches, lectures, course outlines and notes are arranged alphabetically by title. Loram's reviews and other people's writings are in alphabetical sequence by author's name.

The writings relate to Christian missionary work, underprivileged people in foreign nations and the United States, race relations, educational systems, anthropological studies of various cultures and South Africa. The college notebooks and notes cover courses in language, psychology, history and law at Kings College, Cambridge University. The material from the Boulder Conference in July, 1947, concerns the American Indian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Government Records in this series are from the South Africa Native Affairs Commission. Included are reports of the Commission to the Minister of Native Affairs, records, laws, and policy statements dealing with the natives and extracts from letters received at the Pensions Office, Pretoria.
The material is arranged in a sequence of general to particular subject area.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes photostats, a diary of Thomas Hargreaves on annexation of Pondoland, notes, material from the report of the Senate Investigation committee on South Africa Native Affairs, and several items of printed material.

scopecontent.p: This series contains three maps of South Africa concerned with the South African Native Affairs Commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pictures concern South Africa. Included are two drawings of wild life by Harold M. Millar and two reproductions of native art.
